awd_titl_txt: IUCRC Planning Grant University of Pittsburgh: Center for Advanced Magnetics for Power and Energy Development (AMPED)
awd_abstract_narration:
Trends towards electrification are driving the needs for improved soft magnetic materials that can operate at unprecedented combinations of switching frequencies and power levels, as well as engineered components which are highly power dense yet extremely efficient.  These trends are also creating major new economic opportunities for the domestic US, through anticipated growth in electric vehicles, hybrid-electric aircraft, and distributed renewable generation amongst others.  The primary emphasis of the proposed Center for Advanced Magnetics for Power and Energy Development (AMPED) will be the critically important area of high-power magnetics and the optimization of interfaces with both established and emerging electrical machine topologies and designs within this application class.  Successfully tackling challenges and exploiting these opportunities as a nation and an economy requires interdisciplinary skills spanning materials science, applied physics, and electrical engineering, as well as collaborations between end-users of components (motors, transformers, inductors, etc.) and the materials and manufacturing community.  The proposed AMPED center seeks to address this need for a new generation of an interdisciplinary workforce of the future that is prepared and eager to take on the new challenges presented by widespread adoption of electrification and growth in electric power conversion technologies.

Primary research thrust areas included within the AMPED portfolio include: (1) new magnetic materials and manufacturing for wide bandgap and ultra-wide bandgap semiconductors, (2) advanced electric machine design concepts, (3) new design and optimization techniques for magnetic components, (4) interactions between wide bandgap power electronics converters and magnetics, (5) advanced power electronics converter topologies enabled by and leveraging next generation magnetics, e.g., multiport power conversion, and (6) tunable and variable magnetics technologies and their applications in advanced power conversion schemes.  Strong collaborations between sites are planned, with unique capabilities residing at each institution: Carnegie Mellon University - amorphous and nanocrystalline magnetic materials and manufacturing, North Carolina State University – wide bandgap-based semiconductor power electronics and high-speed motor controls and testing, University of Pittsburgh – ferrite based soft magnetic materials and electromagnetic field assisted advanced manufacturing, component design strategies, and magnetics / power electronics interfaces.  University of Pittsburgh will serve as lead site and will ensure integration of emerging magnetic materials and manufacturing technologies with advanced magnetic component designs and, ultimately, the integration within electrical machines.  More specifically, University of Pittsburgh will leverage its capabilities and facilities for research spanning: (1) design, synthesis, and characterization of new soft magnetic materials; (2) advanced manufacturing processes including electromagnetic field assisted processing and additive manufacturing; (3) multi-objective optimization and machine learning based design methods for advanced magnetic components and their interface with power electronics converters and motors; (4) power electronics and motor hardware prototype development; and (5) testing and characterization of magnetic components, power electronics converters, high speed motors, and controllers.  University of Pittsburgh offers facilities for medium voltage electric power conversion research and development (up to 15kV, 5MVA) as well as full-scale magnetic material and component manufacturing, design, and testing under conditions directly relevant for electric machine applications.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Division of Engineering Education and Centers

inst.org_lgl_bus_name: UNIVERSITY OF PITTSBURGH - OF THE COMMONWEALTH SYSTEM OF HIGHER EDUCATION

por.por_cntn:
Faculty members from the University of Pittsburgh (Pitt) and North Carolina State University (NCSU) have been developing the Advanced Magnetics for Power and Energy Development (AMPED) consortium focusing, technically, on the R&D for magnetic materials science, including manufacturability and scalability to electrical components like inductors, transformers, and electric vehicle motors and associated power electronic systems that utilize these components like power converters and motor drives.  Holistically, the center seeks to develop a community-based innovation ecosystem with representatives from government, industry, and academia having a technical focus spanning fundamental materials science and manufacturing to full-scale optimized component design.  There exists no other consortium specifically focused on the topic of high power magnetic materials and components within the United States, although there are numerous other centers and consortia for which this topic is critically important for the technologies being explored through center activities.  For this reason, the universities pursued a NSF industry-University Cooperative Research Center (IUCRC) planning grant.

With the support of the one-year planning grant, AMPED faculty engaged in similar project outcomes as other centers who received the grant including the NSF IUCRC bootcamp, engaged with the process of attracting industry to join the center through membership discovery, and hosted an industry planning meeting held in Pittsburgh at the Energy Innovation Center.  The faculty were stretched to firmly list out the value propositions of a future center and, with those listed, search and investigate potential company clients.  The team conducted video conference interviews with more than 35 industry members spanning across the industry (both nationally and internationally) including material suppliers, electrical manufacturers, and national laboratories.  Based upon these interviews and from previous brainstorming prior to the grant, the team was able to confirm that the following research thrusts are appealing to the general audience and include the following, (1) new magnetic materials and manufacturing approaches for wide bandgap and ultra-wide bandgap semiconductors, (2) advanced electric machine design concepts, (3) new design and optimization techniques for magnetic components, (4) interactions between wide bandgap power electronics converters and magnetics, (5) advanced power electronics converter topologies enabled by and leveraging next generation magnetics, e.g., multiport power conversion, and (6) tunable and variable magnetics technologies and their applications in advanced power conversion schemes. 

A highlight of the planning grant cycle was hosting a two-day workshop held in October 2022 at the Energy Innovation Center in downtown Pittsburgh.  This is the location of Pitt's energy enterprises including the AMPED laboratory.  The planning meeting had around 75 registered participants (both in-person and online) including at least 30 different organizations and representation from Pitt and NCSU faculty, students, and university executives.  Because AMPED was founded two years prior to receiving the planning grant opportunity, leadership had to merge the traditional AMPED model (which has a small membership fee) with the NSF IUCRC model.  Both models have keynotes conducted and, this year, we had the former CTO of Wolfspeed provide a discussion on the coupling between semiconductors and magnetics.  We also had a DoE program manager from the Office of Energy Efficiency and Renewable Energy discuss several of the programs tied to electric machines and eliminating rare earth elements.  All of this material dovetailed with the planned presentations from graduate students focused on tunable magnetics and electric motors design.

During the first day of the planning meeting, the PI of this program and NSF program manager laid out the future directions of the center as well as gave an overview of the NSF IUCRC framework.  With the foundation set, AMPED faculty members presented at least 12 new project ideas with written documentation provided before the event and verbally on the first day.  All material was pre-populated into the Airtable for voting in the afternoon of the second day.  To establish a deeper appreciation of the existing projects and how they aligned with the proposed projects, graduate students from both universities assembled 20+ posters that were on display for the entire two-day event with dedicated social hours to ensure the posters received the attention.

Overall, the planning meeting was a success and current and new AMPED members continuously stay engaged with monthly research seminars and another planned meeting for August 2023.


Last Modified: 05/20/2023
Modified by: Paul R Ohodnicki
